contextId.information: This expression refers either to all Jewish Christians living outside of Israel, or, more likely, to all Christians living anywhere in the world. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to the twelve tribes in the dispersion

contextId.information: The term "twelve tribes" normally stood for all the people of Israel, because they had been divided into twelve tribes. In this passage, however, "twelve tribes" stands either for all Jewish Christians or, more likely, for all Christians everywhere in the world. Here "twelve tribes" is used as a title, and the number "twelve" should be written as text, not as a numeral. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the twelve tribes

contextId.information: Here this person is spoken of as if he could not stay on one path but instead went from one to another. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: unstable in all his ways

contextId.information: Someone whom God has honored is spoken of as if he were standing in a high place.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: boast of his high position

contextId.information: Eternal life is spoken of as if it were a wreath of leaves placed on the head of a victorious athlete. AT: "receive eternal life as his reward" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: receive the crown of life

contextId.information: God, who brought us eternal life, is spoken of as if he had given us birth. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: give us birth

contextId.information: People should first listen intently, and then consider carefully what they say. "Slow to speak" does not mean speaking slowly.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: let every man be quick to hear, slow to speak

contextId.information: Sin and evil are spoken of here as if they were clothing that could be taken off. AT: "stop doing all sinful filth and abundant amounts of evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: take off all sinful filth and abundant amounts of evil

contextId.information: Here "filth," that is, dirt, stands for sin and evil. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: sinful filth

contextId.information: The expression "implant" means to place one thing inside of another. Here God's word is spoken of as if it were a plant made to grow inside believers. AT: "obey the message God has spoken to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: receive the implanted word

contextId.information: to not allow the evil in the world to cause oneself to sin (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to keep oneself spotless from the world

contextId.information: Believing in Jesus Christ is spoken of as if it were an object that one could hold onto. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: hold to faith in our Lord Jesus Christ

contextId.information: Having much faith is spoken of as being wealthy or rich. The object of faith may have to be specified. AT: "have strong faith in Christ" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: be rich in faith

contextId.information: James speaks of faith as if it could be seen while one does good works. AT: "I will demonstrate my faith by doing good works" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will show you my faith by my works

contextId.information: James speaks of faith as if it does good works. Abraham's faith in God regarding Isaac enabled Abraham to obey God when it was difficult. By obeying God, Abraham's faith matured. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: faith worked with his works

contextId.information: "God regarded his faith as righteousness." Abraham's faith and righteousness were treated as if they were able to be counted as having value. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: it was counted to him as righteousness

contextId.information: James speaks of works as something to possess. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: justified by works

contextId.information: James is speaking of faith without works as if it were a dead body without the spirit. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: For as the body apart from the spirit is dead, likewise also, faith apart from works is dead

contextId.information: Sinful speaking is spoken of metaphorically as if it stained one's body. And becoming unacceptable to God is spoken of as if it were dirt on the body.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: It stains the whole body

contextId.information: James refers to one's ability to speak evil as if it were a poisonous snake or plant. The poison is the harm those words can inflict on another person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: full of deadly poison

contextId.information: Words that carry blessing or cursing are spoken of as if they were objects coming out of someone's mouth. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Out of the same mouth come blessing and cursing

contextId.information: Good works are spoken of as if they were fruit on trees. AT: "good works" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: good fruit

contextId.information: James speaks of believers as being like a wife who sleeps with men other than her husband. AT: "You are not being faithful to God!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You adulteresses!

contextId.information: Here the idea of coming close stands for becoming honest and open with God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Come close to God, and he will come close to you

contextId.information: The word "double-minded" refers to a person who cannot make a firm decision about something. AT: "double-minded people" or "people who cannot decide if you want to obey God or not" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: double-minded

contextId.information: James speaks of God honoring the humble person as if God would pick that person up off the ground physically, where that person had prostrated himself in humility. AT: "he will honor you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: he will lift you up

contextId.information: James speaks of people as if they were a mist that appears and then quickly goes away. AT: "You live for only a short amount of time, and then you die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: For you are a mist that appears for a little while and then disappears

contextId.information: The idea of fire here is meant to lead people to remember that fire often stands for God's punishment that will come on all the wicked. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: fire

contextId.information: God is spoken of as if he had ears as humans have. AT: "the Lord of hosts has heard" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: into the ears of the Lord of hosts

contextId.information: Here people are viewed as if they were cattle, luxuriously fed on grain so they would become fattened to be slaughtered for a feast. However, no one will feast at the time of judgment. AT: "Your greed has only prepared you for harsh eternal judgment" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You have fattened your hearts for a day of slaughter

contextId.information: James compares Jesus, the judge, to a person about to walk through a door to emphasize how soon Jesus will return to judge the world. AT: "the judge is coming soon" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the judge is standing at the door

contextId.information: Being condemned is spoken of as if one had fallen, crushed by the weight of something heavy. AT: "so God will not punish you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: so you do not fall under judgment

contextId.information: Prayer is presented as if it were an object that was strong or powerful. AT: "When the person who obeys God prays, God will do great things"   (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The prayer of a righteous person is very strong in its working

contextId.information: A believer who stops trusting in God and obeying him is spoken of as if he were a sheep that wandered away from the flock. The person who persuades him to trust in God again is spoken of as if he were a shepherd who went to search for the lost sheep. AT: "whenever anyone stops obeying God, and another person helps him start obeying again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: if anyone among you wanders from the truth, and someone brings him back

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) the person who brings back the disobedient brother will have his sins forgiven or 2) the disobedient brother, when he returns to the Lord, will have his sins forgiven. Sins are spoken of as if they were objects that God could cover so that he would not see them, so that he would forgive them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will cover over a great number of sins
